content.raw:
`ign_find_package()` has no problem with using external config-files and find-modules. We have had two motives for providing our own find-modules for every dependency so far:

1. Having imported targets for every dependency is extremely valuable, for both us as developers *and* for end-users of the libraries. It ensures that all dependencies and configuration settings (like compiler flags) are automatically inherited by the consumer, from the start to the end of the dependency tree. However, since imported targets are a relatively new feature of cmake, many of our dependencies don't provide them. And even when it comes to dependencies that do provide them (e.g. protobuf 3, Eigen 3.3.4), we want to be able to support older versions that don't provide them (e.g. protobuf 2, Eigen 3.2.92), so for those old versions, we still need some find-module logic to create the imported targets in case they don't exist. If we ever have a dependency that provides an imported target for every version of itself that we want to support, then we wouldn't need our own find-module for it.

2. Writing our own find-modules allows us to encode pkgconfig information for each dependency so that `ign_find_package()` can help us automatically generate pkgconfig files for each library and each component. This is something that no cmake config-file (to my knowledge) provides. `ign_find_package()` provides a `PKGCONFIG` argument which allows the dependent project to specify the pkgconfig information; that way, `ign_find_package()` can simply use the external config-file with no issues. However, even in that scenario, we'll probably find it easier to make a find-module that's just a very light wrapper for `find_package(... CONFIG)` and then put the pkgconfig information into our custom find-module; that way, dependent projects don't need to worry about what pkgconfig information to provide.

Edit: Minor terminology correction
content.html:
ign_find_package() has no problem with using external config-files and find-modules. We have had two motives for providing our own find-modules for every dependency so far:

  1. Having imported targets for every dependency is extremely valuable, for both us as developers and for end-users of the libraries. It ensures that all dependencies and configuration settings (like compiler flags) are automatically inherited by the consumer, from the start to the end of the dependency tree. However, since imported targets are a relatively new feature of cmake, many of our dependencies don't provide them. And even when it comes to dependencies that do provide them (e.g. protobuf 3, Eigen 3.3.4), we want to be able to support older versions that don't provide them (e.g. protobuf 2, Eigen 3.2.92), so for those old versions, we still need some find-module logic to create the imported targets in case they don't exist. If we ever have a dependency that provides an imported target for every version of itself that we want to support, then we wouldn't need our own find-module for it.

  2. Writing our own find-modules allows us to encode pkgconfig information for each dependency so that ign_find_package() can help us automatically generate pkgconfig files for each library and each component. This is something that no cmake config-file (to my knowledge) provides. ign_find_package() provides a PKGCONFIG argument which allows the dependent project to specify the pkgconfig information; that way, ign_find_package() can simply use the external config-file with no issues. However, even in that scenario, we'll probably find it easier to make a find-module that's just a very light wrapper for find_package(... CONFIG) and then put the pkgconfig information into our custom find-module; that way, dependent projects don't need to worry about what pkgconfig information to provide.

Edit: Minor terminology correction

content.raw: Thanks, that all makes sense.
content.html: Thanks, that all makes sense.

content.raw:
This question is slightly outside the scope of this PR. 

Are we planning to wrap all cmake configs, rather than directly using a project's installed version? I see the nice features `ign_find_package` brings to the table, but there is also more maintenance on our side.  Is there some other benefit or reason that I'm missing?
content.html:
This question is slightly outside the scope of this PR.

Are we planning to wrap all cmake configs, rather than directly using a project's installed version? I see the nice features ign_find_package brings to the table, but there is also more maintenance on our side. Is there some other benefit or reason that I'm missing?

content.raw:
`EIGEN3_FOUND` seems to be defined also on the newest `Eigen3Config.cmake` that imports the `Eigen3::Eigen` target, see https://bitbucket.org/eigen/eigen/src/92edf0f84c49a3c85df77b592d181abf4de81890/cmake/Eigen3Config.cmake.in#lines-10 . 

Perhaps the order between this and the next `if` block need to be swapped?

Perhaps the order between this and the next if block need to be swapped?

content.raw:
It makes sense to take advantage of the config-mode search. I've added that here: 5525d68

It seems that Eigen's native config-files have been changing in their behavior across different versions, so I'll try to accommodate each of the behaviors that I've encountered so far.
content.html:
It makes sense to take advantage of the config-mode search. I've added that here: 5525d68

It seems that Eigen's native config-files have been changing in their behavior across different versions, so I'll try to accommodate each of the behaviors that I've encountered so far.

content.raw:
Probably it is not essential, but it would be nice to be able to specify the location of a eigen installed in non-canonical location using the `Eigen3_DIR` variable as documented in the official Eigen documentation https://eigen.tuxfamily.org/dox/TopicCMakeGuide.html .
A way of doing this would be to add a `find_package (Eigen3 NO_MODULE)` at the beginning of this script, and guard the rest of the logic on `if(NOT TARGET Eigen3::Eigen)` checks. 

This would also have the nice side-effect to avoid confusion on case insensitive file systems (such as macOS, unless something changed recently). On those platforms, `find_package(Eigen3)` would resolve to this script or to the official `Eigen3Config.cmake` depending on whether `find_package(ignition-cmake*)` have been called or not.
content.html:

A way of doing this would be to add a find_package (Eigen3 NO_MODULE) at the beginning of this script, and guard the rest of the logic on if(NOT TARGET Eigen3::Eigen) checks.

This would also have the nice side-effect to avoid confusion on case insensitive file systems (such as macOS, unless something changed recently). On those platforms, find_package(Eigen3) would resolve to this script or to the official Eigen3Config.cmake depending on whether find_package(ignition-cmake*) have been called or not.

content.raw: On `vcpkg` and Ubuntu 18.04 it should be sufficient to just call `find_package(Eigen3 CONFIG)` to define `Eigen3::Eigen` using the native `Eigen3Config.cmake .

content.html: Using Eigen's native target name is a good idea; we can switch to that.

content.raw:
The upstream Eigen3 project installs a `Eigen3Config.cmake` file (i.e. they refer to the CMake package as `Eigen3`) and since [Eigen 3.3.1](https://bitbucket.org/eigen/eigen/src/f562a193118d4f40514e2f4a0ace6e974926ef06/cmake/Eigen3Config.cmake.in?at=3.3.1&fileviewer=file-view-default#Eigen3Config.cmake.in-6) a relocatable `Eigen3::Eigen` is exported .

There is any specific reason for choosing instead `EIGEN3` as cmake package name and `EIGEN3::EIGEN3` as target name? 

Old but related issue in `ros/cmake_modules` : https://github.com/ros/cmake_modules/issues/25 .
content.html:
The upstream Eigen3 project installs a Eigen3Config.cmake file (i.e. they refer to the CMake package as Eigen3) and since Eigen 3.3.1 a relocatable Eigen3::Eigen is exported .

There is any specific reason for choosing instead EIGEN3 as cmake package name and EIGEN3::EIGEN3 as target name?

Old but related issue in ros/cmake_modules : https://github.com/ros/cmake_modules/issues/25 .

content.raw: I made some changes to allow `ign_pkg_check_modules[_quiet]` to import INTERFACE targets: 4c248d8. We should make sure to test this against all downstream ignition projects before merging.
content.html: I made some changes to allow ign_pkg_check_modules[_quiet] to import INTERFACE targets: 4c248d8. We should make sure to test this against all downstream ignition projects before merging.
